LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  People's Republic of China (PRC) 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention

Subsector: Roads and highways 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth and regional cooperation

Environment   Category A. An environmental impact assessment was completed; the 
Assessment  summary was circulated to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Board 
and made public through the ADB website on 9 April 2007.  
   
Project Description  The Project is located in western Guangxi, one of the poorest areas in 
the PRC. With a per capita gross domestic product that is 63% of the 
national  average,  Guangxi  ranks  27th  among  the  31 administrative 
areas.  The  Project  is  designed  to  promote  pro-poor  sustainable 
economic  growth  in  western  Guangxi,  preparing  it  to  cope  with  an 
increasingly important role in regional cooperation and trading with Viet 
Nam. The Project will provide an integrated road transport network in 
western Guangxi by (i) constructing the 177 kilometer (km) Longlin–
Baise  expressway;  (ii)  upgrading  the  associated  1,060  km  of  local 
roads;  (iii) improving  road  transport  services  by  constructing 
50 township  bus  stations  and  implementing  passenger  bus  route 
licensing reforms; (iv) improving road maintenance by implementing 
rural  road  maintenance  policy  reform;  and  (v)  improving  corporate 
governance  and  strengthening  institutional  capacity  by  providing 
consulting services, equipment, and training. 
   
Rationale  Underdeveloped  roads  and  transport  services  are  major  causes  of 
poverty in Guangxi. Rural poverty incidence is 30% in the project area, 
particularly  in  the  border  area  with  Viet  Nam.  Existing  transport 
infrastructure is currently being used to saturation levels, creating high 
transport costs for producers and consumers. This transport bottleneck 
needs to be removed to facilitate the movement of goods and people 
between  rural  and  urban  areas  and  between  interior  and  coastal 
provinces. 
 
The Project will improve an important national transport network by 
building  a  section  from  Baise  to  Longlin  (Guizhou  border)  of  the 
Kunming  (Yunnan)–Shantou  (Guangdong)  corridor,  one  of  the  high 
priority east–west corridors in the PRC. It will connect the poor and 
isolated interior provinces (Guizhou, Yunnan, Sichuan) and the city of 
Chongqing to the nearest seaports in Guangxi (Beihai, Fangcheng, and 
Qinzhou) and Guangdong (Map 2). 
 
The Project is one of the high priority projects identified by the Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Transport  Sector  Strategy,  which  was 
endorsed by the six GMS governments at the 11th meeting of the GMS 
Transport Forum in Vientiane, Lao People’s Democratic Republic in 
2006.  The  Project  will  provide  the  missing  link  in  the  Kunming–

iv 
Nanning–Hanoi section of the GMS economic corridor. The Project will 
(i) improve border roads and transport services for trade activities, and 
(ii) provide facilities and equipment to meet expected demand for freight 
transshipment and storage at the border crossing point in Pingxiang 
(international land port with Viet Nam). It will link Nanning and Kunming, 
the two major growth centers in the western PRC to Hanoi (Viet Nam), 
supporting  the  strategic  thrust  of  strengthening  connectivity  and 
facilitating cross-border movement and tourism with Viet Nam (Map 1).  
   
Impact and  The Project will contribute to pro-poor sustainable economic growth in 
Outcome  western  Guangxi  and  northern  Viet  Nam.  This  will  be  achieved  by 
developing  an  efficient,  safe,  and  environment-friendly  regional 
transport system to promote trade in, and through, western Guangxi 
and reduce trade barriers with Viet Nam.

Plan  equivalent. Of the $300 million ADB loan, $40.26 million will finance 
nonexpressway  components  including  rural  roads  ($28.6  million), 
township  bus  stations  ($1.4  million),  border-trade  logistics  center 
($10 million), rural transport service demonstration project ($0.16 million), 
and a rural road maintenance study ($0.1 million).

Consulting Services  The ADB loan will finance 45 person-months of international consulting 
services  for  supervising  construction;  providing  advice  on  structural 
engineering,  pavement,  road  safety,  road  transport  services,  and 
corporate  governance;  and  formulating  a  capacity  development 
program. The international consultants will be recruited in accordance 
with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
The Project will also finance national consulting services for the (i)  rural 
transport  services  demonstration  project,  and  (ii)  rural  road 
maintenance policy reform study, each at an estimated cost of no more 
than $100,000. The required national consultants will be recruited in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  In 
addition, GCD will engage and finance 7,700 person-months of national 
consulting services. All national consultants, not financed by ADB, will 
be recruited in accordance with government procedures acceptable to 
ADB. 
   
Project Benefits  The expressway forms part of the Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi section of 
and Beneficiaries  the GMS economic corridor, which is a major artery for the regional 
transport network connecting with national and regional roads. It will 
have a significant, positive impact on the economic development of the 
region. 
 
The expressway will reduce travel time by at least 3 hours and shorten 
the travel distance between Baise and Longlin by 34 km. Improved 
local roads will link villages to the road network and border areas with 
Viet Nam, and hence to the national and regional economy. Improved 
rural  transport  services  will  link  rural  households  with  the  wider 
economy. A developed and efficient transport network will integrate 
poor  isolated  regions  with  the  centers  of  economic  growth.  The 
economic internal rate of return for the Project is 17.5%. The financial 
internal rate of return is 4.5%, which is higher than the real weighted 
average cost of capital. The Project will directly benefit about 2.3 million 
people in Baise, of whom 87% live in rural areas and 30% of these live 
on  less  than  $1  per  person  per  day.  The  Project  will  also  benefit

240 million people indirectly in the southwestern region of the PRC. 
More  broadly,  the  Project  will  benefit  the  three  poor  northeastern 
provinces in Viet Nam adjacent to Guangxi with a total population of 
2.3 million. 
 
The Project will directly benefit road users (e.g., passengers, traders, 
transport providers, and bus and truck operators), as well as labor, the 
local economy, and the private sector. The Project will help reduce 
traffic accidents, vehicle emissions, and traffic noise in the corridor. The 
Project will also boost tourism. Rural households are also important 
beneficiaries, and will benefit from increased incomes through better 
access  to  roads,  transport  services,  markets,  off-farm  opportunities, 
and better access to trade services. The Project will create 18.6 million 
person-days of local employment amounting to CNY318 million in wage 
payments  during  construction,  and  another  CNY20  million  of  wage 
payments expected to go to the local communities annually after start 
of project operation. A total of 18,500 local people are likely to gain 
employment and skills training throughout the Project. The ability and 
skills  of  local  communities  will  be  greatly  enhanced.  The  improved 
regional transport system will enhance the local investment climate to 
attract more investment to the region and act as a catalyst for future 
investment.  
   
Risks and  The  Project  is  formulated  to  reduce  technical,  economic,  financial, 
Assumptions  safety, and social risks. The main technical risks are associated with 
the construction of tunnels and bridges. Project preparatory technical 
assistance  consultants  have  reviewed  the  proposed  design  and 
construction methods and found them in order. During implementation, 
the bidding system will focus on contractors’ financial and technical 
capabilities in handling similar complex works. Monitoring and contract 
management  information  systems  will  be  set  up  to  quickly  identify 
technical  and  environmental  problems  and  correct  them.  The 
contractors will be required to strictly enforce work safety rules and 
measures. GCD has experience and has performed satisfactorily in 
internationally financed projects. 
 
The financial risk associated with construction and operation of the 
expressway will depend on traffic volume, capital cost, and toll rates. To 
mitigate the financial risks, GCD will build up a commercial business 
environment  for  expressway  operations,  the  Project  will  receive 
substantial injections of equity from central and provincial governments, 
and a market-oriented toll structure will be adopted. The Project has no 
major environmental, resettlement, or HIV/AIDS infection risks; and has 
mitigation and monitoring mechanisms in place. GCD demonstrated 
significant ownership in preparing the resettlement plan, environmental 
impact assessment, and ethnic minorities development plan.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Western Guangxi Roads Development Project. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The PRC has made remarkable progress in economic growth and poverty reduction 
since the late 1970s. However, its gross domestic product (GDP) per capita is still modest, and 
about 135 million people living on less than $1 day consumption line (more than 10% of the 
global poor).1 Moreover, the distribution of income is highly imbalanced between eastern coastal 
and interior provinces and between urban and rural areas. Poverty is more widespread in the 
western region. Infrastructure constraints and lack of access to consumer markets are the main 
causes of the region’s high incidence of poverty. Thus, developing economic infrastructure in 
key corridors, including seaport links and trade corridors connecting the western and coastal 
regions, is essential to promote trade and reduce regional development disparities in the long run. 
 
3.  Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (Guangxi) is one of the five autonomous regions  
(equivalent to a province) in the PRC. Guangxi has highlands in the northwest and lowlands in 
the southeast, and mountains on three sides. Since Guangxi is the only western province with a 
coastline, it assumes a very important role in the Western Region Development Program. 
Guangxi borders Guangdong province in the east, Hunan and Guizhou provinces in the north, 
Yunnan in the west, and Viet Nam in the south. Hence, it provides a strategic link between the 
resource-based economies in the western PRC and the trade-oriented economies in the eastern 
PRC. The proposed Project forms an integral part of the east–west trade corridor connecting the 
southwest hinterland provinces with coastal provinces. Together, the five provinces (Guizhou, 
Yunnan, Guangxi, Chongqing city,2 and Sichuan) have a population of about 240 million, about 
19% of the country’s total. Support for developing the proposed corridor will extend the benefits 
of increased accessibility to the west region, where average incomes are the lowest in the PRC. 
 
4.  Like  other  parts  of  the  PRC,  Guangxi’s  economy  has  grown  rapidly.  Nevertheless, 
Guangxi still lags the coastal provinces and the country as a whole. With a per capita GDP of 
CNY8,788 in 2005 (63% of the national average), Guangxi ranks 27th of 31 administrative areas. 
Guangxi’s per capita GDP is only about one third of Guangdong province. The lack of an 
efficient and effective transport system is an important constraint for the sustainable growth of 
Guangxi. Although road density by area or by population is comparable to the national average, 
road density by area (2.61 kilometers [km] per 1,000 square km) is only 40% of Guangdong 
province; and class-II and above roads comprise 13% of all roads, or half of Guangdong 
province. Guangxi has a 1,595 km coastline. Given its geographic location, transport corridors in 
Guangxi need to be developed into the western region and within Guangxi. 
 
5.  Developing  markets  becomes  more  important  as  the  PRC  becomes  more  open 
economically. The openness ratio, measured as the ratio of foreign trade to GDP, reached 60% 
in 2005 from 31% in 1991. Coastal provinces benefit from much greater shares of investment 
and foreign trade than inland provinces. Guangdong accounted for 30% of the PRC’s foreign 
trade in 2005. The southwestern region, including Guizhou, Yunnan, Guangxi, Chongqing, and

country’s population, it accounts for only 3.2% of total foreign trade; it has yet to benefit from the 
trade-led growth. Since the use of transport infrastructure is essential to any trade-oriented 
economy, the western region needs to improve its infrastructure to attract investment to develop 
enterprises that take advantage of abundant raw materials and relatively low labor costs. If 
western provinces are to have an important share of the country’s total trade, access to these 
provinces must improve, and constraints on the transport of trade overcome. 
 
6.  More than 90% of the poor in the PRC live in rural areas. Roads usually are the only 
mode of transport that can help the poor reach markets and services. Recognizing the role of 
rural roads in reducing poverty, the Government has accelerated rural road improvement to 
close the development gap between urban and rural areas.3 During the 10th Five-Year Program 
(FYP) 2001–2005, investment in rural roads totaled CNY418 billion, three times that in the 
previous 5 years. By 2010, all villages will have road access, and all townships will have paved 
roads. Paved roads will link all eastern villages, 88% of central villages, and 50% of western 
villages. To achieve this, the indicative plan prepared by the Ministry of Communications (MOC), 
envisages investment in rural roads to reach about CNY800 billion (about $100 billion) from 
2006  to  2010.  Of  this,  MOC  will  provide  CNY140 billion,  representing  17.5%  of  the  total 
investment; the provinces and domestic and foreign loans will finance the remainder. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Challenges 
 
7.  Despite rapid economic growth, the PRC has suffered from imbalanced growth among 
the provinces. In 2005, the GDP per capita of the western provinces was about half of the 
national average and only one third of that in the eastern coastal region. The road network still 
does not provide adequate access to the poorer inland region; vast distances and difficult 
mountainous terrain isolate it from local, regional, and national markets. Most exports and 
imports  reach  major  markets  through  other  provinces,  meaning  that  regional  transport 
development is an important determinant of growth and development. 
 
8.  Guangxi has made significant progress in poverty reduction since 1990s as a result of 
economic growth and concentrated development efforts. Nevertheless, it remains one of the

26.  Improving Rural Transport Services. Despite good progress in providing rural transport 
services connecting townships with counties, some villages still do not have roads and bus 
services. In the project area, passenger bus productivity (the average daily kilometers driven per 
passenger bus) is very low (30 km/day on average for small buses). This reflects low demand,

28.  Introducing Weight-Based Tolls. To control overloaded vehicles, GCD will implement 
weight-based tolling for all expressways and parallel toll highways by the end of 2007. The 
principle behind weight-based tolling is that goods-carrying vehicles pay a rate per ton-km 
based on the weight class of the vehicle plus a penalty rate per excess tonnage. Experiences 
gained in other provinces show that this is an effective way to manage overloaded vehicles if 
complemented with effective control measures. For example, after introducing the weight-based 
tolls, overloaded vehicles were reduced from 40% to 17% in Shandong province, and from 65% 
to 13% in Anhui province (Appendix 7).

emissions: imposing regulations on the automobile industry, requiring an annual vehicle test, 
and improving the vehicle inspection and maintenance program. The new measures also set 
emission  and  fuel  efficiency  targets,  and  offer  tax  incentives  for  manufacturers  of  more 
environment-friendly cars. Guangxi follows national vehicle emission control strategies including 
enforcing national emission standards for new vehicles, improvement of conventional fuels and 
alternative or cleaner fuels, vehicle inspection and maintenance programs, and retirement of

6.  Rationale for ADB Support 
 
30.  Constraints and Opportunities. Rural poverty incidence is very high in the project area 
(Map 3). Roads and transport services are underdeveloped, which is a major cause of poverty. 
Existing  transport  infrastructure  is  currently  being  used  to  saturation  levels,  creating  high 
transport costs for producers and consumers. This transport bottleneck needs to be removed to 
facilitate moving goods and people between rural and urban areas, and between interior and 
coastal provinces. At the national level, the Project will connect interior provinces, now poor and 
isolated, to the nearest seaports in Guangxi and Guangdong. At the regional level, the Project is 
one of the high priority projects identified under the GMS Transport Sector Strategy,19 endorsed 
by the six GMS governments at the 11th meeting of the GMS Transport Forum in Vientiane, Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic in March 2006. It is also included in the Strategy for the Closer 
Integration of Guangxi into the GMS, and GMS Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program 
Update (2007–2009).20 The Project will provide the missing link in the Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi 
transport corridor, which will support the GMS strategic thrust for strengthening connectivity and 
facilitating cross-border trade and tourism with Viet Nam (Map 1).

B.  Outputs

C.  Special Features 
 
35.  Border-Road Improvement for Trade Activities. This includes upgrading three border-
road sections totaling 50 km: (i) the Jingxi–Longbang road is an important link integrating the 
transport system and the planned development of the land ports in Longbang and Yuexu; and 
(ii) two border access roads, one accessing a border livestock market and a planned border 
“trading street,” and the other providing improved access to a new border facility and freight 
station. The improvements will facilitate access to border ports to stimulate border trade, create 
employment opportunities, and increase regional cooperation with Viet Nam. The border road 
upgrading will serve strategic border development projects that are expected to result in a

significant increase in trade and traffic. By lowering transport costs and improving the transport 
links to the Viet Nam border at Pingxiang, Longbang, and Yuexu, the Project will spur economic 
activity and interregional and international trade, helping reduce poverty over a wide region, 
including on both sides of the border. The ADB loan will provide $13.2 million to finance border-
road improvements for trade activities (Appendixes 10 and 11). 
 
36.  Rural Road Improvement for Network Integration. This comprises three rural road 
sections  totaling  260  km  linking  to  expressway  interchanges  and  thereby  integrating  the 
expressway to the local road network and rural areas. It will help spread the benefits to the poor 
and minorities, who are mainly farmers and dependent on local road networks to reach markets. 
Better  connections  between  the  expressway  and  rural  roads  will  enable  more  agricultural 
products to reach markets and allow farmers to upgrade their farming practices. As reliable 
transport to markets becomes more readily available, cash crop farming in remote or isolated 
areas will be stimulated and access to off-farm employment opportunities will be broadened. 
Fresh and high-value-to-weight agriculture products will be made profitable to market due to 
lower transport cost. The ADB loan will provide $12.4 million to finance rural road improvement 
for network integration (Appendix 10). 
 
37.  Village Road Improvement for Poverty Reduction. The primary objective of the village 
road improvement is poverty reduction. Under the recently completed World Bank financed 
Southwest Poverty Reduction Project, Guangxi Poverty Alleviation and Development Office 
(GPAO) learned that (i) improving rural infrastructure was a powerful and fast-acting measure to 
improve well-being and poverty, and (ii) utilizing an integrated approach is very effective for 
addressing severe poverty. A major innovation, led by GPAO under the World Bank project, was 
support for village access roads. The improved access roads had important synergistic effects 
on other project activities (for example, with road access, schools and heath clinic construction 
was made much easier and materials such as chemical fertilizer for agricultural activities were 
more easily transported to the area). The project preparatory interviews observed that poor 
households  were  extremely  supportive  of  projects  implemented  by  GPAO.  Working  in 
collaboration with GPAO, the Project will provide $3 million to rehabilitate 750 km of 4,000 km of 
rural roads in the project area following the village roads implementation framework (VRIF) 
agreed upon with GCD. The VRIF, as presented in Supplementary Appendix B, integrates a 
resettlement framework; environmental framework; and technical, procurement, and financial 
management framework.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
56.  The existing national highway is congested and carries high traffic volume. The Project 
will increase the corridor’s capacity to meet transport demand and will significantly reduce 
transport costs and travel times. The expressway will reduce the trip length between Baise and 
the Guizhou border by 34 km and result in time savings of at least 3 hours. Traffic on the 
expressway is forecast to grow from an average 6,330 passenger car units per day in 2012 to 
an average of 30,500  per day in 2032. To reflect experience in previous projects, the opening 
traffic projection considers the “ramp-up” effect (footnote 17) on expressways immediately after 
opening (Appendix 17). 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
 
57.  The  project’s  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  estimated  by  comparing 
scenarios with and without the Project. The project’s economic costs reflect (i) the capital cost 
for construction including physical contingencies, land acquisition, and resettlement; (ii) O&M 
costs,  which  include  replacing  depreciated  equipment  and  periodic  maintenance;  and 
(iii) environmental monitoring costs. The economic benefits are (i) savings in vehicle operating 
costs as a result of reduced road length, and improved traffic and road conditions; (ii) time 
savings for road users; (iii) savings in road accident costs as a result of fewer accidents; and 
(iv) benefits from generated traffic. The Project is economically viable. The EIRR for the whole 
Project is 17.5%. The EIRR is 17.1% for the expressway, 21.7% for the local road network, and 
29.2% for the rural transport service component. Sensitivity analysis confirms the robustness of 
the project’s economic viability (Appendix 18 and Supplementary Appendix G). 
 
C.  Financial Analysis and Projections 
 
58.  The proposed toll rates23 for the project expressway are considered reasonable to attract 
sufficient traffic to meet the criteria for the economic and financial internal rates of return. 
Financial projections have been prepared in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Financial 
Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). Projected financial statements indicate that its 
internal financial revenues will be sufficient to cover O&M costs and debt service from the sixth 
year of full operation. The expressway financial internal rate of return is estimated at about 4.5% 
after  taxes—better  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  3.3%,  also  net  of  taxes. 
Sensitivity analysis indicates that the financial internal rate of return is robust under adverse 
conditions.  The  Project  is  considered  to  be  financially  viable  and  sustainable.  Financial 
management assessment found that the Project meets the minimum financial management 
requirements and can provide accurate and timely information on its status in the reporting 
format agreed with ADB (Appendix 19 and Supplementary Appendix H).

meetings  and  field  surveys.  GCD,  local  governments,  and  residents  express  tremendous 
support  and  emphasize  the  need  for  the  Project;  and  they  participated  in  the  project 
identification  and  planning  process.  Current  government  program  (such  as  comprehensive 
village poverty reduction program) in the project area will be ongoing throughout the life of the 
Project.  Specific  objectives  of  the  government  program  include  improvements  to  living 
conditions of rural poor through improved rural infrastructure, training, micro credit, access to 
drinking water, increased arable land, improved housing, and biogas facilities. The government 
program will complement activities undertaken by the Project, which provides an integrated 
approach for addressing poverty. 
 
H.  Risks 
 
69.  The project design has considered potential technical, financial, and social risks. The 
main technical risks are associated with the design and construction of many bridges and 
tunnels. To minimize technical risks, (i) the Project will be implemented by experienced staff; 
(ii) preliminary  design  will  focus  on  detailed  geotechnical  investigations;  (iii)  international 
consultants will help prepare a risk management plan; (iv) the bidding system will focus on 
financial  and  technical  capabilities  of  contractors  in  handling  similar  works;  (v)  a  contract 
management information system will help identify technical problems and implement corrective 
measures on time; and (vi) given the safety hazards associated with bridge and tunnel works, 
the contractors will be required to strictly enforce working safety rules and measures. To control 
the financial risks, the Project will (i) strengthen contract management, (ii) inject more equity into 
the Project, (iii) introduce a market-based approach to formulating tolls and regularly reviewing 
toll rates to ensure cost recovery, and (iv) build a business environment to generate nontoll 
revenues. Social issues include resettlement and HIV/AIDS infection. Appropriate mitigation 
measures are in place in the resettlement plans and EMDP. GCD demonstrated high ownership 
in preparing and committing to implement these action plans. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
70.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government, GRG, and GCD have given the 
following specific assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
71.  GCIG. The Government will ensure that (i) by 31 October 2007, (a) the GCD working 
group  completes  the  restructuring  plan  and  all  preparations  for  consolidation  of  relevant 
expressway operations of GIAB, GEAB, and SWEC, in GCIG (either as operating divisions or 
subsidiaries), and (b) a copy of the report of the GCD working group is submitted to ADB; (ii) by 
31  March  2008,  a  corporate  development  plan,  a  concession  agreement,  an  onlending 
agreement, and a draft charter for GCIG, are finalized by GCD and submitted to ADB; and 
(iii) by 30 June 2008, GCIG is incorporated/registered, the restructuring plan is implemented in

20 
accordance with its terms, and the concession agreement and the onlending agreement are 
duly executed. 
 
72.  Financial Ratios. The Government will ensure that GCIG will maintain (i) a working ratio 
(annual O&M cost, but excluding periodic maintenance cost, to revenue) of not more than 15%, 
(ii) a debt service coverage ratio of not less than 1.2 from the 6th year of its full operation, and 
(iii) maintain a minimum equity investment of 35% of the project cost.  
 
73.  Private  Sector  Development.  GCD  will  explore  the  possibility  of  attracting  private 
sector investment by potential investors in close consultation with ADB. Furthermore, 6 months 
prior to the opening of the project expressway, GCD through GCIG will analyze the feasibility of 
tapping the financial markets for financing future road sector investments, including possible 
private sector participation in O&M of the project expressway, and report its conclusions to ADB. 
 
74.  Rural  Passenger  Bus  Route  Licensing  Reforms.  GCD  will  ensure  that  the  rural 
passenger bus route licensing reforms are implemented in Baise City to improve road transport 
efficiency; and will issue necessary decrees, regulations, and guidelines for its implementation. 
 
75.  Road Safety. Prior to construction and operation of the project expressway and local 
roads, GRG will cause GCD to (i) establish a road safety interagency committee to facilitate 
project implementation, and (ii) ensure that the independent road safety audits are carried out 
and the recommendations of these audits are taken into account during project construction and 
operation. At least 6 months prior to the opening of the project expressway, GRG will (i) through 
GCD, develop and implement a plan to ensure safe operation of road infrastructure facilities; 
and (ii) establish a sufficient number of teams of traffic police personnel, in accordance with the 
national law and GRG standards, to patrol the project roads, and enforce national regulations. 
 
76.  Rural  Road  Maintenance. GRG shall cause GCD to (i) implement the rural roads 
maintenance policy reforms as approved by GRG, and (ii) provide a training program during the 
project implementation to strengthen the capacity of local government maintenance units and 
local communities. GRG shall cause the local governments to ensure adequate funding and 
effective management of the Project’s rural roads. 
 
77.  Village Access Road Program. GRG, through GCD, will ensure that the village access 
road program is implemented in accordance with the VRIF, which is an integrated framework 
comprising  resettlement,  environmental,  technical,  procurement,  and  financial  management 
frameworks. 
 
78.  Environment. GRG, through GCD and its bureaus and GCIG, will ensure that (i) the 
Project is designed, constructed, implemented, and operated in accordance with environmental 
laws and regulations of the Government and ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and the EIAs, 
IEEs, and environmental assessment review procedures as contained in the VRIF; (ii) the EMP 
and the mitigation measures included therein, as specified in the EIAs, IEEs, and environmental 
assessment review procedures, as applicable, are properly and promptly implemented; (iii) the 
EMP and mitigation measures included therein are updated at the engineering design stage and 
incorporated into the bidding documents and civil works contracts; (iv) any adverse impact on 
the environment that may arise from project implementation activities is promptly mitigated or 
minimized in accordance with the EMP; (v) any major accidents, including any safety breaches, 
violation  of  environmental  standards,  and  corrective  measures  taken  thereto,  are  reported 
forthwith to ADB; (vi) semiannual reports on the implementation of the EMP are submitted to 
ADB,  and  ADB  is  allowed  to  conduct  annual  environmental  reviews;  and  (vii) reports  and 
information are provided to ADB on request to enable it to verify that the goods and services

financed out of the proceeds of the loan have been produced in a responsible manner with a 
view to resource efficiency, waste minimization, and other environmental considerations. 
 
79.  Vehicle Emissions. At least 6 months prior to the opening of the project expressway, 
GRG  will  ensure  that  Guangxi  Environmental  Protection  Bureau,  Guangxi  Public  Security 
Bureau, and other agencies enforce the national vehicle emission standards, and fulfill the 
requirements of the policies and regulations of the Government. 
 
80.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. GRG through GCD will ensure, and cause its 
bureaus to ensure, that (i) the resettlement plans and resettlement framework, as contained in 
the VRIF, for the Project are implemented in accordance with their terms, (ii) all land and rights-
of-way required for the Project are made available in a timely manner, (iii) the provisions of the 
resettlement  plans,  including  compensation  and  entitlements  for  affected  persons,  are 
implemented in accordance with all the PRC’s applicable laws and regulations and ADB’s 
Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), (iv) compensation and resettlement assistance is given 
to the affected persons prior to their dispossession and displacement, and commencement of 
civil  works,  (v)   timely  provision  of  counterpart  funds  is  made  for  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement activities, (vi) any obligations in excess of the resettlement plans budget estimates 
are promptly met, (vii) the affected persons are at least as well off as they would have been in 
the absence of the Project, (viii) resettlement plans are updated upon completion of the detailed 
design  and  detailed  measurement  survey  and  submitted  to  ADB  for  approval  prior  to 
commencement of civil works, (ix) adequate staff and resources are committed to supervising 
and  monitoring  implementation  of  the  resettlement  plans  and  satisfaction  of  ADB's  report 
requirements; (x) an independent agency acceptable to ADB is engaged by GCD to monitor and 
evaluate results of implementation of resettlement plans and forward reports to ADB and GCD 
as required; and (xi) a summary of the final government audits of resettlement disbursements 
and expenditures are submitted to ADB. 
 
81.  Ethnic Minorities Development. GRG through GCD will ensure, and cause its bureaus 
to ensure, that (i) the EMDP is implemented in accordance with its terms; (ii) targeted ethnic 
minorities benefit from the Project at least equitably and in accordance with ADB's Policy on 
Indigenous Peoples (1998); (iii) civil works contractor specifications include requirements to 
comply with the EMDP and as a priority to provide employment to ethnic minority people, 
(iv) adequate staff and resources are committed to supervising and monitoring implementation 
of the EMDP and report progress to ADB in the quarterly progress report; (v) an independent 
agency acceptable to ADB is engaged by GCD to carry out investigations to monitor and 
evaluate progress annually, and forward reports to ADB and GCD simultaneously; and (vi) data 
is disaggregated by gender, and monitoring includes gender impacts. 
 
82.  Labor  Standards. GCD will cause the concerned local communications bureaus to 
ensure that all employment and labor standards provided in the applicable laws and regulations 
of the PRC are complied with, and in particular, that all civil works contractors engaged under 
the Project (i) provide timely payment of wages on at least a monthly basis and safe working 
conditions to all workers including male and female workers, with such requirements being 
included in the civil works contracts and monitored by the construction supervision consultants; 
(ii) provide employment opportunity to women and ethnic minorities, where appropriate, and pay 
equal wages to male and female employees for equivalent works; and (iii) not employ child labor 
in the project works. 
 
83.  Gender and Development. GRG through GCD will ensure, and cause its bureaus and 
GCIG to ensure, that ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998) is followed during 
project implementation and necessary steps are taken to encourage women living in the project

22 
area  to  participate  in  planning  and  implementation  of  the  Project,  including  causing  the 
contractors  to  maximize  their  employment  of  women  in  connection  with  the  Project.  GRG 
through GCD will monitor, as set out in resettlement plan and EMDP, the effects of the Project 
on women during project implementation. 
 
84.  Health Risks. GRG through GCD will ensure that its bureaus and GCIG, in coordination 
with the Guangxi Health Department and its agencies, (i) disseminate to transport operators and 
local communities, and (ii) cause the contractors to disseminate, information on the risks of 
socially  and  sexually  transmitted  diseases,  including  HIV/AIDS,  to  their  employees, 
subcontractors, and families during project implementation. GRG through GCD will cause, and 
have its bureaus and GCIG to cause, the contractors to (i) ensure their workers have regular 
health checks and (ii) monitor health risk control according to the Implementation Methods of 
Epidemic Prevention Law of the Borrower, and in accordance with the methods specified in the 
EMDP. 
 
85.  Axle Loads. By 31 December 2007, GRG will ensure that GCD installs vehicle axle-
weighing equipment on all expressways and parallel toll highways, and implements weight-
based tolls. Six months prior to the opening of the project expressway, GCD through GCIG will 
submit to ADB for review the proposed toll structure and rates before seeking GRG approval. 
 
86.  Change in Ownership. In the event that GRG, GCD, or GCIG plan to make (i) any 
change in ownership of the project facilities; or (ii) make any sale, transfer, or assignment of 
GCD or GCIG’s interest in the project expressway, or (iii) lease out, or contract out, or otherwise 
materially modify GCD or GCIG’s responsibilities for O&M of the project expressway, GRG shall, 
at least 6 months prior to implementation of such plan, consult with ADB and obtain ADB's 
consent. GRG shall ensure that such transfer is made in a lawful and transparent manner.

RURAL TRANSPORT SERVICES AND POLICY REFORM 
 
A.  The Rural Transport System in Guangxi 
 
1.  Rationale. The project’s transport services component comprises a program of building 
bus stations and introducing associated bus route improvements through licensing reforms. 
Together with the expressway and rural road improvements, it will help establish an integrated 
rural transport service network and raise the accessibility of the areas served. Cheaper, more 
frequent, more reliable, and safer transport services will improve access to jobs and education, 
and health and welfare services; raise incomes from the sale of produce; increase the range of 
goods  and  services  available  locally;  and  improve  access  to  information  on  prices  and 
marketing opportunities. As well as encouraging these service improvements, the bus stations 
will themselves offer employment opportunities, create a market for small-scale traders (of food, 
drinks,  etc.)  and  businesses  (e.g.,  vehicle  maintenance  and  repair),  improve  access  to 
information by public telephone, and provide better amenities for passengers. 
 
2.  Transport Services. In Guangxi, formal passenger services in rural areas are mostly by 
6–8-seat minibuses or 15–20-seat buses. They are licensed to stop only at designated places 
and stations, but few towns and none of the villages have stations, even simple stops. Where no 
formal services are available, the informal sector plays an important role, especially on poorer 
quality roads, but their safety standards are deficient and they are often more expensive than 
formal services. Generally, bus services are good along routes between county and township 
centers, but do not exist between villages and are rare between villages and townships. Overall, 
in 2005, all townships had a formal service, but 580 administrative villages and 3,654 natural 
villages in the project area did not have a formal service. 
 
3.  Regulatory Framework. Guangxi Transport Administration Bureau (GTAB) is the main 
agency involved in road transport administration in Guangxi. The bureau is responsible for 
regulating the road transport industry by licensing intercity bus services.1 County communications 
bureaus  are  responsible  for  the  regulation  of  road  transport  within  provinces.  Licensing 
conditions for bus services, routes, and stations are restrictive, requiring buses and drivers to be 
confined to their authorized routes and schedules to be fixed by station operators. While freight 
tariffs are fully deregulated, passenger fares are allowed to vary within narrow bands around 
guideline rates set by Guangxi Communications Department (GCD). 
 
4.  Transport Demand and Users’ Needs. Most trips in rural areas are to buy and sell 
produce and for work. The average household in the project area makes 22 trips per annum to 
their nearest township and only 4 to their nearest county center; the poor travel much less. 
Where formal services, which charge CNY0.10–CNY0.20 per kilometer (km), are unavailable, 
fares on informal services are expensive: as much as CNY0.40–CNY0.50 per km. Consequently, 
half of all trips by poor households are on foot (bicycles are unsuited to the mountainous terrain), 
even over distances of up to 14 km. On average, transport accounts for 4%–8% of household 
expenses. For poor villages and those with poor road access, the proportion is much higher. To 
help reduce costs and encourage expansion of services, Guangxi discounts selected fees and 
taxes for buses that have at least 20% of their route on roads of class IV or lower. Some 
6,798  buses benefited from this in 2006. 
 
5.  Issues and Priorities for Improvement. Bus productivity in the project area is very low: 
170 km per day on average for medium-sized buses and less than 30 km per day for small 
buses, according to official statistics. This reflects low demand, poor roads, and inefficient 
scheduling of vehicles; in turn a function of long waiting times at stations and inability to rotate

MAIN FEATURES OF THE PROJECT EXPRESSWAY 
 
1.  The project expressway is located in the northwest of Guangxi. Most of the alignment is 
mountainous with altitudes of 100–800 meters (m) and natural gradient of over 20 degrees. The 
expressway will be a 177 kilometer (km), four-lane access-controlled tollway from Baise to the 
border with Guizhou province in Longlin county, which is one of the high priority east–west 
corridors in the People’s Republic of China. The expressway connects at the south with the 
Nanning–Baise Expressway and at the north with the planned Guizhou–Kunming expressway in 
Xingyi city. It will go through the Youjiang district of Baise, Tianlin, and Longlin counties. The 
following paragraphs describe the alternatives considered. 
 
2.  Do-Nothing  Alternative.  The  do-nothing  option  would  require  traffic  to  use,  as  at 
present, the existing road, national highway 324. This highway is already operating at close to 
capacity and would require substantial upgrading, first to a divided class-II standard to carry 
projected normal growth traffic, and then by 2022 to class-I or expressway standard. Upgrading 
the existing road would require significant realignment to provide adequate capacity and reduce 
roadside friction, especially in the northern section, and require the upgrading of many bridges 
and tunnels. The tunnels and bridges would have to be constructed to class-I or expressway 
standard initially to prevent major expensive upgrading later. The combined cost of initial and 
later upgrading of the road could well approach the cost of the new expressway, while providing 
an  inferior  alignment  but  involving  significant  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  decreased 
safety, and less total capacity. For this reason, the do-nothing option is not recommended. 
 
3.  Road Class Analysis. The option of constructing a road of lower technical class instead 
of the project expressway was considered but rejected for the following reasons: (i) The only 
road classes with the capacity to carry traffic up to 2022 are four-lane expressway or class-I 
highway. (ii) The major difference between the expressway and class-I highway according to 
Ministry of Communications (MOC) design standard is that class-I highway may be only partly 
access-controlled  whereas  an  expressway  must  be  fully  access-controlled.  Thus,  the 
construction costs differ only in the number and types of access control by overpass or grade 
separation, which accounts for about 3%–5% of the total cost. (iii) Reducing access control and 
grade separation reduces capacity and safety.

standard, the road capacity for design speed of 80 km/hour is 25,000–45,000 passenger car

and Viet Nam increased from $8.2 billion in 2005 to $9.9 billion by 2006, i.e., 21%. The PRC is 
Viet Nam’s second-largest trading partner; excluding Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, 
it accounted for 12.6% of trade in 2005. Small-scale border trade between Viet Nam and 
Guangxi, within administrative districts on both sides and no more than 20 km from the border, 
grew by 50% to $1 billion in 2006. Three provinces in Viet Nam’s northeast region are adjacent 
to Guangxi—Quang Ninh, Lang Son, and Cao Bang, with a population of 2.33 million in 2005—
are among the poorest in Viet Nam. Support for developing cross-border trade will contribute to 
pro-poor economic growth in western Guangxi and northern Viet Nam. 
 
2.  Regional  Cooperation.  Regional  cooperation  is  strongly  supported  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) 2006 strategy for regional economic cooperation and integration,1 
and strategy and program for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), which includes goals of 
facilitating cross-border movements and tourism, and integrating markets to promote economic 
efficiency and private sector development. The PRC and Viet Nam cooperate under GMS 
initiatives; Guangxi joined the GMS in 2004. The GMS strategic framework for action on trade 
facilitation  and  investment  covers  four  key  activities:  customs  procedures,  inspection  and 
quarantine  measures,  trade  logistics,  and  mobility  of  people.  The  GMS  countries  are 
implementing provisions of the Cross Border Transport Agreement to simplify and harmonize 
cross-border transport procedures and promote integrated logistics. 
 
3.  Border Trading Ports. Four main crossings of Guangxi’s 637 km border with Viet Nam 
are at Dongxing, Pingxiang, Shuikou, and Longbang, all national class-I land ports through 
which international transport is authorized. In addition, there are seven class-II land ports, as 
well  as  25  border  trade  markets.  Regional  trade  through  Youyiguan  will  benefit  from  the 
project’s improved expressway connections to/from Yunnan, Guizhou, and areas further west 
and north and associated facilities. Two of the others, Longbang (class I) and Yuexu (class-II), 
will benefit from upgraded rural roads upgraded, which will establish good-quality links to the 
project expressway via Jingxi, Debao, Tianyang, and Baise; and serve border trade flows 
to/from Guangxi, Guizhou, Yunnan, and beyond. Passenger services to/from Longbang and 
Yuexu will be improved by a program of bus stations and bus route reforms.  
 
B.  Project Components 
 
4.  Aside from providing the missing link in the Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi transport corridor, 
the Project includes components with strong GMS dimensions, i.e., (i) provision of facilities and 
equipment to meet expected demands for freight transshipment and storage at the Wantong 
Logistics  Center  in  Pingxiang  (para.  5),  (ii)  border  road  improvement  for  trade  activities 
(Box A11);  and  (iii)   bus  station  (para.  6)  and  pilot  bus  route  licensing  improvements 
(Appendix 6), which will improve the efficiency and quality of bus services. 
 
5.  Trade Facilitation at Pingxiang. Discussions are under way between the governments 
of  the  PRC  and  Viet  Nam  to  expand  the  existing  bilateral  road  transport  agreement  on 
exchanges  of  traffic  rights  along  the  Nanning–Hanoi  corridor.  Agreement  is  expected  by 
31 December 2007. The opening of the Wantong Logistics Center in October 2006 at Pingxiang 
provided a major impetus to cross-border trade along the Nanning–Hanoi corridor, one of the

Box A11: Border Roads Improvement for Trade Activities 
 
 
 
Jingxi-Longbang Road. Along Jingxi county’s 152 km border with Viet Nam are Longbang class-I land port; 
 
Yuexu class-II port; and four border markets in Longbang, Yuexu, Xinxing, and Mengma. The current poor and 
  low capacity of the existing Jingxi–Longbang road cannot meet the demands of the increasing traffic, both local 
  and cross-border. The road upgrading is to serve traffic using the land ports and border markets. It will integrate 
  the transport system in the area with planned development of the land port. Improved access to international 
trade at Longbang and Yuexu will pass on the benefits of reduced travel costs on the expressway to poor 
 
counties in the project area, simulate border trade, and create employment opportunities. 
   
  Naxi (Longbang) Border Market Access Road. The road section near Longbang passes through Naxi village, 
  the site of Guangxi’s only livestock border market, trading some 300 head of cattle, horses, goats, and pigs each 
day, mostly benefiting small-scale producers. Jingxi has plans to expand this facility, almost doubling its capacity. 
 
In addition, some 1,000 small-scale traders cross the border every day, trading agricultural produce, utensils, 
 
poultry, livestock, fruit, timber, etc. with people from adjacent Vietnamese townships. Jingxi has approval for a 
  plan to develop a border trade street at the Naxi border, to provide improved facilities for traders and help 
  generate local employment. The Project is expected to increase annual border trade by CNY100 million, raise 
  CNY10 million per annum in taxes and tariffs, and increase local incomes by CNY5 million. Thus upgrading of this 
road is crucial to local development. 
 
 
  Yuexu Border Access Road. The road is located at a class-II land port opposite Pobiao port in Viet Nam. Trade 
  is mostly in cement, animal feed, manganese, herbs, and foodstuffs. An estimated 50,000 people cross the 
  border each year, mostly small-scale traders exchanging agricultural goods, foodstuffs, and consumer products. 
This will increase substantially when the planned new border freight station is constructed and the Vietnamese 
 
finish upgrading their road to Trung Khanh. The road will serve small-scale cross-border traffic and the new 
 
transshipment facility to be constructed behind the present border post. 
 
 
 
6.  Bus Stations. To facilitate cross-border trade, the Project includes two class-II bus 
stations at Longbang and Yuexu, which currently do not have formal bus stations. Buses stop at 
the roadside, interrupting traffic and market activities and posing a safety risk. At Longbang, at 
the end of the route, buses have difficulty turning for their return journey and have no off-street 
space to wait for passengers. The proposed location of Longbang bus station is close to the 
center  of  town,  near  the  existing border  crossing  and  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations Free Trade Area (AFTA) being developed to handle export traffic. The proposed Yuexu 
bus  station  is  adjacent  to  Yuexu  town  center  and  will  be  integrated  with  a  major  freight 
transshipment facility and border trade market. Experience in Guangxi has been that transport 
services respond to road improvements, with bus operators taking advantage of better access 
to areas of potential demand. This is expected to result in more trade and investment, better 
information on market opportunities, and higher incomes for the poor.

RURAL ROAD MAINTENANCE POLICY REFORM 
 
1.  Existing  Situation.  Adequate  and  timely  maintenance  is  important  to  ensure  the 
sustainability of rural roads. In Guangxi, county communication bureaus are responsible for rural 
roads maintenance, and the quality of rural roads is periodically monitored by city and provincial 
highway administration bureau. In Baise, county roads in good condition account for 62% of the 
total county road network, and there is an urgent need to upgrade rural roads and improve the 
maintenance. Main issues associated with rural road maintenance are: (i) poor road quality; 
(ii) insufficient  funding,  (iii)  inadequate  planning,  (iv) limited  implementation  capacity,  and 
(v) lack of market-oriented approach and framework.  
 
2.  Rural Road Maintenance Policy Reform. In line with its "people first" development 
strategy and the desire to create a socially harmonious society, the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) Government has taken several actions. In 2005, the PRC State Council launched the 
Policy Reform for Rural Road Maintenance. In December 2006, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous 
Regional People’s Government (GRG) issued a rural road maintenance reform, which is being 
introduced in three trial cities in Guangxi (Box A12). Experience from the trial cities will be 
replicated in other areas.  
 
 
Box A12: Guangxi Rural Road Maintenance Policy Reform 
 
 
 
•  Demarcate responsibilities with county governments. 
    County governments are the main administrators for rural road maintenance. 
    Local governments should manage the fund, and ensure proper maintenance of rural roads. 
  •  Stipulate a specific ratio of the road maintenance fee collected for road maintenance. 
Eighty percent of the road maintenance fee collected from motorized vehicles by local governments after 
 
deductions (such as collection costs, traffic police, and water conservancy construction fund) should be used 
 
for road maintenance. 
    By 2010, 100% of the road maintenance fee collected from motorized vehicles by local governments after

  •  Impose a minimum level of funding for major road maintenance.

•  Impose minimum funding for routine road maintenance. 
    The allocation will not be lower than CNY5,000 per km per annum for county roads, CNY2,500 per km per 
  annum for township roads, and CNY1,000 per km per annum for village roads. 
  •  Introduce a market-oriented mechanism.

3.  Improve Rural Road Maintenance in Baise. To ensure the sustainability of the project, 
GCD agreed to implement the rural road maintenance policy reform in Baise. GCD will ensure a

effectively using it for maintenance, planning, and operations; (iii) adjusting its organization 
structures  and  training  programs  to  devote  more  resources  to  rural  maintenance,  and 
(iv) increasing competitive and market-based procurement of maintenance services through

5.  Rural  Road  Maintenance  Study.  ADB  held  an  in-depth  dialogue  during  project 
preparation that led to a good understanding of rural road maintenance issues and of how to 
address them. The Project will support GCD initiatives to implement policy reform by identifying 
and test market-based mechanism and technologies that offer possibilities for improving the 
quality and efficiency of road maintenance. To achieve this objective, a rural road maintenance 
study will be conducted under the Project to develop an effective maintenance mechanism and 
regulations. Guangxi Highway Administration Bureau (GHAB) will be responsible for the study, 
which will be supported by $100,000 of the ADB loan. The study will review road maintenance 
issues in Guangxi and focus on the following areas (paras. 6–9). 
 
6.  Effective Maintenance Mechanism. Surveys will be carried out to review current road 
maintenance practice and identify needs for improvement based on international and domestic 
experience. The review will focus on funding and its source, institutional arrangement, new 
technologies in maintenance, maintenance standards, road condition survey and assessment, 
short- and medium-term maintenance program, budgeting, and market-based procurement and 
activities. Based on the output of the review, experiences relating to market-based effective 
mechanisms and new technologies will be analyzed and tested under the study. The study will 
prepare an action plan for wide-scale implementation of good practices and modalities. 
 
7.  Rural Road Maintenance Handbook. To provide practical guidance for crew leaders 
and workers, a rural road maintenance handbook will be developed. It will make use of current 
available handbooks (both international and domestic practice) and maintenance codes; and 
incorporate more information on labor, application of necessary equipment, appropriate data 
collection, treatment for various defects, and development of human resource management and 
safety at work. The handbook will cover the maintenance activities for paved and unpaved 
roads, road facilities and drainage, and environment and work zone safety issues. 
 
8.  Road Inventory and Condition Databank. The study will review the road inventory and 
condition databank prepared by GCD to identify the current status and application situation. The 
review  may  include  (i)  inventory  data;  (ii)  condition  data;  (iii)  data  collection  and  update; 
(iv) funding,  institution,  equipment,  and  staff  to  maintain  the  databank;  (v) function  and 
application of the databank; and (vi) the function and attributes of the digital road network. The 
study will recommend improvements and actions plans to utilize the databank more effectively. 
 
9.  Relevant  Training.  At  least  300  persons-months  of  training  and  dissemination  of 
information will be included in the study, which may include the use of the handbook, concept of 
life-cycle cost, and the benefit of market-oriented implementation mechanism. The attendees of 
training session will be relevant subnetwork managers, county and township authorities, crew 
leaders, local communities, and contractors.

1.  The  project  expressway  forms  a  key  section  of  the  east-west  Kunming  (Yunnan)–

The Project is also one of the sections of the proposed Guangxi regional expressway network. 
Connected with the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed Guangxi Roads Development II 
Project (Nanning–Baise expressway), it will provide the shortest route to seaports and the 
border between the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Viet Nam for inland southwest 
provinces in the PRC such as Guizhou, Sichuan, and Yunnan. 
 
2.  In Guizhou, the expressway will connect the planned expressway from Banba (Guangxi 
border) to Jiangdi (126 kilometers [km]; the prefeasibility study was already approved and 
construction will start in 2007; completion is targeted for 2012). In Yunnan, it will connect from

expressway will be opened to traffic in 30 June 2008; the Nanning to Youyiguan and Youyiguan 
to Hanoi sections are functioning well. By 2012, the Kunming–Nanning–Hanoi section of the 
Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor will be completed. 
 
3.  The project expressway will be built parallel to the existing national highway (NH) 324, a 
major class-III road. The pavement condition of most of road is poor due to the many heavy 
loaded trucks that travel its length. Much of the highway is in mountainous country and has tight

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
1.  General. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project, as the indicator of 
economic analysis, was estimated by comparing the situation with and without the Project. 
Without the Project, traffic will continue to use the existing road network, national highway (NH) 
324, which will be more congested and expensive to maintain due to rapidly increasing traffic 
volume, causing delays and resulting in increased travel time, vehicle operating cost (VOC and 
road accidents. With the Project, traffic will benefit from faster, cheaper, and safer travel due to 
rapid reduction of congestion along the corridor. Some additional trips will be generated as the 
economy responds to lower transport costs and better services. Some traffic will be diverted 
from other road networks in the corridor. 
 
2.  Assumptions.  The  economic  analysis  incorporates  5  years  of  implementation  and 
20 years of operation. Economic evaluation was undertaken using 2007 prices, expressed in 
CNY using the domestic price numeraire with a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.013 for 
foreign  exchange  effects.  Unskilled  labor  is  valued  using  a  shadow  wage  rate  factor  of 
0.7 considering the low productivity and unemployment in the area. The economic costs of the 
expressway include (i) the capital costs, including physical contingency, land acquisition and 
resettlement,  and  environmental  mitigation  costs;  and  (ii)  the  costs  of  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) for the expressway, including the costs of replacing depreciated equipment 
and periodic maintenance. The economic benefits include (i) savings in VOC resulting from 
reduced travel distance and improved road conditions; (ii) savings in the value of passenger 
time tied up in transit; (iii) savings resulting from fewer accidents; (iv) benefits to generated 
traffic; and (v) savings in capital and O&M costs for NH324. 
 
3.  Expressway  Component.  The  project  expressway  will  shorten  the  route  by 
34 kilometers (km). The calculations of VOC savings allow for differences in roughness, terrain, 
speed, and congestion; and also for a changing vehicle mix for both passenger and freight 
vehicles, and improvements in vehicle performance. The typical economic VOCs are shown in 
Table A18.1. Travel time savings are valued for passengers in vehicles only, as the time of crew 
members  is  valued  in  the  VOC.  They  are  valued  at  25%–75%  of  the  average  wage  of 
passengers on the project expressway. The values used per person-hour are CNY5.47 for car 
passengers and CNY1.04 for bus passengers. The economic costs of accidents are estimated 
in terms of direct property damage and forgone income on the basis of national data for 2005. 
The  average  economic  cost  of  an  accident  is  estimated  at  CNY108,800  on  expressways, 
CNY93,000 on class-II roads, and CNY70,000 on class-III roads. The benefits of generated 
traffic are estimated at half the VOC and time savings of normal traffic as a proxy for willingness 
to pay. In addition, savings in capital and O&M costs for NH324 are calculated on the basis of 
maintaining a volume-to-capacity ratio of 1.0 without the Project. The EIRR for the expressway 
component is estimated at 17.1%, indicating that the Project is economically viable, with a net 
present value of CNY4,206 million. 
 
4.  Rural Road Component. The rural roads for upgrading under the Project were chosen 
based on the effect on overall road network efficiency and benefit-cost analysis, economic 
development potential, and population density. The rural road costs include capital costs and 
O&M costs. The principal benefits of the local road improvement are identified as (i) VOC 
savings (Table A18.1), (ii) benefits to generated traffic, and (iii) savings in O&M costs. The rural 
roads have a combined EIRR of 21.7% per annum with net present value of CNY504.3 million.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): 
Despite rapid economic growth, the PRC’s GDP per capita was still modest (CNY14,040) in 2005, with the absolutely 
poor population of 26.1 million and a low income population of 49.8 million. Using the international poverty line of 
$1/day consumption poverty line, the country still has about 135 million poor. The PRC’s 11th Five-Year Program 
places a strong emphasis on rural development with a pledge to increase farmers’ incomes and enhance public 
services in the countryside. 
 
The country program and strategy update for the PRC (2007–2008) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) seeks to 
promote sustainable economic growth and reduce poverty through transport sector in ADB operations in the PRC. This 
Project directly contributes to these objectives by improving road transport efficiency and improving the access of rural 
villages to income-generating opportunities and social services. More poor villages will have improved connectivity as a 
result of expressway, rural road, and transport service improvements, which will help create the conditions necessary 
for developing local resources and generating employment to raise living standards. 
 
The ADB’s regional cooperation strategy and program update for the Greater Mekong Subregion (2007–2009) support 
harmonizing cross-border trade and improving transport infrastructure. The Project will directly contribute through road 
improvements and bus stations near the border with Viet Nam. This will promote regional cooperation by improving 
cross-border trade, transport services, and livelihoods of the poor living in the border area.  
 
The Project is also aligned with ADB’s poverty reduction strategy, which focuses on aligning ADB operations with a 
country’s own poverty reduction strategy and fostering of partnerships. Accordingly, the project’s social and poverty 
interventions were prepared in the context of Guangxi’s poverty reduction and development plans. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis         Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
The project area covers one district and seven counties. It has a population of 2.3 million with a poverty rate of 30% 
and 7% of residents live in absolute poverty. Ethnic minorities comprise 80% of the population; 36% are poor. The road 
improvements will lead to lower transport costs, improved transport services, improved access to markets and social 
services, increased competitiveness, expansion of economic opportunities, diversification of rural livelihoods, and 
poverty reduction. Farmers will benefit from reduced transport costs, better access to markets, increased opportunities 
for diversification, and increased competition for their products leading to increased incomes. This will promote 
diversification and significantly enhance the impact of local development programs on farmer’s incomes and community 
development.  The  Project  will  increase  economic  development  in  the  area  and  the  growth  of  off-farm  income 
opportunities including jobs during implementation. The rural transport services improvements will help establish better 
transport services providing improved efficiency and affordability, thereby increasing services to poor villages. The 
improved rural transport network will provide better access to jobs, markets, health care, schools, and other services; 
and will increase the range of goods and services available in the community. The Project will also facilitate cross-
border trade, much of which is undertaken by small-scale traders, many of who are women. The improved roads and 
more open border between the PRC and Viet Nam will also help to boost tourism development. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes        No 
Project surveys and community participatory consultations were carried out in preparing the poverty and social strategy 
with priority given to rural areas, especially poverty-stricken villages and ethnic minority villages. This provided an 
understanding of the concerns and constraints facing farmers and gave villagers the opportunity to express transport-
related concerns and opinions of both positive and negative impacts arising from the Project. In total, 979 households in 
the project area were surveyed. According to local residents, the greatest benefits will be increased economic 
development in the area resulting in increased income sources and more job opportunities. Farmers had a keen 
understanding of the direct link between transport costs and farm profit margins and expected lower freight costs and 
improved access to benefit them directly.  People also placed a good degree of  emphasis on a cleaner environment

with less dust and easier and faster transport. Residents also stated improved roads would provide better access for 
children traveling to schools and improve road safety.

villagers will be consulted to minimize losses of high-quality arable land and structures. Township governments and 
community organizations will be directly involved in the implementation of the resettlement plans and EMDP. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Rural women participate actively in agricultural production in the project area; this, together with child care, care of the 
elderly, animal care, and household chores, results in heavy workloads for women. Local programs to improve rural 
household living conditions, such as biogas systems and sanitation and drinking water facilities, have brought benefits 
to women, particularly to poor women in mountain communities. Nevertheless, female illiteracy is considerably higher 
than male illiteracy and women’s health situation, especially in mountain communities, is poor. 
 
The Project will benefit women significantly and not have an adverse impact on women or children. They will benefit 
from easier transport, time savings, and improved access to medical facilities and other social facilities; and from a 
general improvement in the quality of life. Women will benefit from greater access to information, jobs, and increased 
opportunities for selling and buying goods at markets. The participation strategy will give priority to women for benefits 
and protection against social risk; special gender measures are included in the EMDP and resettlement plans. Gender 
disaggregated indicators will be monitored by the project performance management system.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 
1.  One  resettlement  plan  covers  the  177  kilometers  (km)  expressway  and  related 
connector roads, interchanges, toll stations, and service areas; while the other four resettlement 
plans  cover  the  local  roads  (310  km).  A  resettlement  policy  framework  and  procedural 
guidelines address the 750 km of village roads and 50 township bus stations. The location of 
towns where bus stations will be built is known, but sites have not yet been decided. The village 
roads will be selected during implementation. Prior to commencement of land acquisition and 
house demolition, Guangxi Communications Department (GCD) will update all resettlement 
plans based on a detailed measurement survey and submit them to the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) for approval.  
 
2.  The  proposed  expressway  and  its  connector  roads  will  affect  10  townships  and 
35 administrative villages in Longlin and Tianlin counties, and Youjiang district of Baise. The 
preliminary design estimates that 1,475 hectares (ha) of land will be acquired, of which about 
38% is farmland (comprising 12.6% paddy fields, 13.3% dry land, and 12.1% orchards), 42.5% 
forestland, 13% wasteland, and 6.5% other. Based on the standard of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) for impact assessment, the equivalent of 3,990 residents would lose all their land 
and agricultural livelihoods. Since the expressway will actually cross many parcels of scattered 
farmland, the average loss of land per household is estimated at 20%, which means 19,950  will 
be partially affected. Another 245 ha of land is estimated to be occupied temporarily during 
construction. Also, 140,400 square meters (m2) of houses will be demolished, necessitating 
relocation of 1,390 rural households involving 4,000 people. The six local roads will require 
283 ha of land, which partially affects 10,200 people; 178 households will be relocated. 
 
3.  The resettlement objective is to ensure equal or better income and living standards, so it 
will be implemented in accordance with the PRC Land Administration Law (2004), State Council 
Document No. 28, and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). GCD agreed that (i) for 
the expressway, Guangxi Communications Infrastructure Administration Bureau will apply the 
national standard for land compensation, which requires a minimum of 16 times annual average 
output value; (ii) for the three local roads, Guangxi Highway Administration Bureau will apply the 
land  compensation  standards  based  on  Document  No.  39  issued  by  Guangxi  Zhuang 
Autonomous Regional People’s Government; and (iii) for the village roads, the ownership of the 
roads and lands will be retained by the relevant village collective. The land compensation 
standards used for all components are sufficient to meet replacement cost. The relevant village 
committees will ensure that those affected will be compensated through the provision of reserve 
land,  land  readjustment,  cash  payment,  or  payment-in-kind.  For  demolished  structures, 
replacement value will be based on compensation rates in Baise. Those losing housing will be 
able to acquire new housing sites within their existing group or village, and close to a road. All 
sites  will  be  provided  with  water  supply,  electricity,  telephone  and  television  cable,  where 
available.  The  relocated  families  will  receive  moving  allowances  and  temporary  housing 
allowances. 
 
4.  Detailed  resettlement  and  rehabilitation  plans  for  seriously  affected  villages  will  be 
developed and included in the updated resettlement plan for the expressway component. Based 
on consultations, most people affected prefer to get cash compensation directly to be used to 
expand businesses, improve animal husbandry, plant cash crops and trees, and provide income 
security until they find outside work. New employment and income generation opportunities will 
arise during construction and after the expressway is completed. Expressway contractors will 
give priority to affected households in the allocation of unskilled jobs during construction.

Appendix 22  69 
5.  Resettlement will be implemented by local governments with supervision by GCD to 
ensure compliance with the approved resettlement plans. For the expressway component, the 
Resettlement Division within the Longlin–Baise Expressway Construction headquarters will be 
directly  responsible  for  coordinating  the  planning,  supervision,  financing,  and  reporting  of 
resettlement for the expressway and connector roads. A resettlement leading group and office 
was established in Baise on 20 October 2006. Offices will also be set up in all the relevant 
counties, and staff assigned in all affected townships and villages to implement resettlement. 
For economically vulnerable people, including elderly living alone, disabled, households headed 
by women, and poverty households, the Project will provide additional training and physical 
support. For these measures, GCD has agreed to a budget of 1% of basic resettlement fees. 
 
6.  The 2004 Land Law requires disclosure and consultation with people affected. Affected 
villages were notified about the key elements of the resettlement plans during meetings and 
interviews. Information was disclosed through newspapers to all those affected in March 2007. 
During detailed resettlement planning, further notifications and consultations will discuss specific 
impacts and how they will be addressed. In case of grievance, all complaints will be processed 
based on the resettlement plans on Grievance and Redress. 
 
7.  The requirements for internal and external monitoring and evaluation are included in the 
resettlement plans. GCD will engage a qualified domestic monitor to carry out independent 
monitoring and evaluation. The monitor will conduct a baseline survey prior to resettlement, 
semiannual investigations during resettlement, and annual survey updates for 2 years after 
completion of resettlement; and will provide ADB and GCD with copies of the reports. For the 
expressway component, an internal monitoring and reporting system will be established in the 
Resettlement Division of the Longlin–Baise Expressway Construction headquarters and report 
to ADB on the progress of land acquisition and resettlement through quarterly progress reports 
and a resettlement completion report. A summary of the resettlement audit will be provided to 
ADB prior to the project completion review mission. For the other project components, internal 
monitoring will be done by GCD and the land and resources bureaus; progress will be reported 
to ADB every 6 months. 
 
8.  The resettlement budget for the expressway is estimated at CNY600 million, for 6 local 
roads  at  CNY90  million;  and  for  other  components  at  CNY10  million.  Costs  include 
compensation for land, housing, other assets, moving allowances, assistance for vulnerable 
groups,  infrastructure,  administration,  taxes,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  contingencies. 
GCD will supplement the resettlement budget, as necessary, to meet any shortfall that emerges. 
 
9.  The  land  acquisition  and  housing  demolition  for  the  expressway  component  will 
commence by September 2007. For the local roads and bus stations, some implementation will 
commence in 2007; village road construction will commence in 2008.
